comment.author: 32162360@N00
32162360@N00
comment._content: Other Hall photos of the 'Malabar' on the ANMM flickrstream - www.flickr.com/search/?w=33147718@N05&q=malabar

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: Ahh thanks Beachcomber :) So the NMA has a print of that Hall image from the scuba site, dated 2/4/1931. They look as though they were taken on the same day bit.ly/XaL1kl. I wonder if Hall and Samuel Hood ran into each other out at the wreck site?!?
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Apologies - I failed to notice that the other photos were by Samuel Hood - oops. I don't know how long the wreck took to break up to this stage; the actual shipwreck happened on Thursday 2 April, and all over the Easter weekend huge crowds (500,000+) came to look. I imagine Hall and Hood were competing with each other to flog souvenir photos! GoogleMapsSatellite view of the wreck site - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Malabar,+New+South+Wales&hl... -33.968263, 151.260137

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thank you for the link. We had it down that between 100,000 and 120,000 people came to see it. In any case, it was A LOT of people!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons]Indeed, enormous crowds and traffic jams. I cannot remember where my 500,000 came from. The SMH gives 150,000 by the Saturday of the Easter weekend, and gives a very vivid description, including photographers, banjo-players and a snake-charmer. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16767088

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Nothing like a bit of clever enterprise amidst a shipwreck. It was the days of economic hardship, often referred simply as 'depression', so people had to make their own way. Thanks for the interesting article beachcomber!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
